title: Why did Lord Ram banish Sita to forest? | Sri Sampati Dasa
speaker: HG Satya Gaura Chandra Dasa

segments.key_quote: It is very important to have spotless character to continue to be king and queen.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the question of why Lord Ram banished Sita, emphasizing the importance of a leader's spotless character and public perception.
segments.transcript: Did Lord Shri Ram doubt his beloved wife, Mother Sita, especially after she gave Agni Pariksha? Today, we all demand that our leaders should be corruption free. If there are any allegations of corruption, we ask them, resign from your post. Just because an ordinary citizen passed in your comments, they had this doubt that whether she is fit. Oh, look how Ram has become so blindly attached to his wife. He is so lusty. It is very important to have spotless character to continue

segments.key_quote: So it was very important for king and queen to have spotless character and that inspires the citizen also to follow the dharma marga, the righteous path.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Lord Ram and Sita, as king and queen, needed to maintain a spotless character to inspire citizens to follow dharma, drawing a parallel to modern expectations of corruption-free leaders.
segments.transcript: to be king and queen. Did Lord Shri Ram doubt his beloved wife, Mother Sita, especially after she gave Agni Pariksha? Just because an ordinary citizen passed in your comments on Sita's character? No, never. Lord Shri Ram never doubted his wife, Sita. Then how do we understand? Then why did he send Mother Sita to forest just because of somebody doubting the character of Sita? It is because we need to understand Lord Shri Ram and Sita, they are not just husband and wife. They are also the king and queen of Ayodhya. As a king and queen of Ayodhya, it is very important to have spotless character to continue to be king and queen. So when the citizens had this doubt that their queen was with some other man for one year, they had this doubt that whether she is fit to continue to be queen of Ayodhya. Like today, we all demand that our leaders should be corruption free. If we come to know or if we get a doubt that this leader is involved in some gotala, there is some corruption charges, we many times we see people asking them to step down. We ask them resign from your post because you know you have to prove that you are corruption free. If there are any allegations of corruption, you cannot continue to occupy the post of a minister. Similarly, in those days, it is not just corruption, it was also character which was more important, right. So it was very important for king and queen to have spotless character and that inspires the citizen also to follow the dharma marga, the righteous path. If the king and queen themselves have a dubious character, compromised character, immoral, unethical, that will encourage the citizens also to follow

segments.key_quote: So Lord Ram and Mother Sita were teaching that to their citizens by themselves having spotless character.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Lord Ram and Sita were teaching their citizens by setting a moral example, explaining that Ram distanced himself from Sita as a queen due to public doubt, but maintained his relationship with her as a husband.
segments.transcript: adharma. In their life, so it is not just enough for the king and queen to do economic development and give all the facilities in the citizen, there also should be inspiring figures to follow dharma, to follow morality, to follow ethical good behavior, conduct. So Lord Ram and Mother Sita were teaching that to their citizens by themselves having spotless character. So Mother Sita, as a queen, her character was doubted. That is why Lord Sri Ram, till her character was proven again, asked Mother Sita to be away from the politics of Ayodhya or away from the palace, away from the king's life. As a king, he distanced himself from the queen. As husband, he always

segments.key_quote: Rama gave the glorious position of wife to mother Sita only, not to anyone else, not that he rejected Sita.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of Rajasuya Yagna to illustrate that Lord Ram never doubted Sita's character as his wife, even though he distanced himself from her as queen due to public doubt, highlighting the golden statue of Sita used in the Yagna.
segments.transcript: maintained his highest relationship with Mother Sita. He never doubted Mother Sita's character. When Ram did Rajasuya Yagna, Rajasuya Yagna or any Yagna can always be done by a married person with his wife, because wife has equal rights to participate in Yagna. At that time, Sita was at the forest. As a ideal king, Lord Sri Ram, distanced himself from Queen Sita, whose character was under question. But, as a loving husband he never doubted his beloved wife Sita. Rajasuya is an example for this. Rajasuya Yajna was done by kings and when Lord Shri Ram was about to do Rajasuya Yajna, the priest in Ayodhya questioned Lord Shri Ram, where is the wife? Because without wife, you cannot perform Rajasuya Yajna alone. At that time, Lord Shri Ram as loving husband got golden statue of Sita, his beloved wife and along with that golden statue Sita, he completed Rajasuya Yajna. If Lord Ram had any doubt about Sita's character, why would he do golden statue of his wife Sita? He gave that glorious position of his wife. In the Rajasuya Yajna, he said that only Sita is eligible to be part of Rajasuya Yajna as my wife. He never rejected Sita as his beloved wife. Yes, queen whose character was under doubt, the public had the doubt, not the king Ram, husband Ram especially. So Rajasuya Yajna episode tells us Rama gave the glorious position of wife to mother Sita only,

segments.key_quote: But Lord Sri Ram is very different leader. He chose nation. He chose the growth of the country first.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts Lord Ram with modern leaders who prioritize their families, emphasizing that Ram chose the nation and its citizens' welfare over his personal life.
segments.transcript: not to Sita. Not to anyone else, not that he rejected Sita. And another very important lesson that many people miss out is the topic of Parivarvaat, today we hear. Today we hear how leaders, powerful people and those occupy the leadership and powerful position in our country do everything for their own family, for their family members, right? At the cost of their own family members, they do everything for their own family members. At the cost of citizens at the cost of the growth of the country. They're very happy to see their family growing, the family property growing, and being with family, being together family, they say, no, no, no, I can't be in the jail. I want to be with my wife. I want to be with my children. But what about country's growth? Nobody cares. But Lord Sri Ram is very different leader. He chose nation. He chose the growth of the country first. He chose the citizens' comfort first, not his personal life. He kept his personal life away from the country. Where do we find such great leaders today? Ram is an inspiration for all the leaders.

segments.key_quote: He said in his kingdom, citizens can without any fear even question the credibility of the king and queen.
segments.summary: The speaker highlights Lord Ram's tolerance of criticism, contrasting it with authoritarian regimes, and explains that Ram distanced himself from Sita as queen to allow an impartial judgment of her character.
segments.transcript: Today, it is very hard to find people who keep their family away and country first. Today, sometimes we hear like in the example of Bangkok in Thailand, there is a monarch dynasty. If you pass any comments, negative comments on the king or that dynasty, you will be jailed. You will be sent to jail. In fact, you may be sentenced. The life sentence be given for those who talk against the royal family. Lord Ram was a monarch. He had all the power in his hand. He could have immediately won. He could have immediately executed those who commented on mother Sita. But he didn't punish those who passed comments on the Sita. He said in his kingdom, citizens can without any fear even question the credibility of the king and queen. He did not threaten the citizen. He did not scare the citizen. I am the powerful person. How dare you talk on my family members? He was okay to be questioned. A king also can be questioned, he said. For that, he could have easily taken the side of Sita. And he said, no, I know the character of my wife Sita. He did not appear to be Parivarwadi. He said, let other authorities justify the Sita's character. Like today, we go to Supreme Court. If there is any corruption charge, the government themselves cannot say we are clean. We are clean. If there is any allegation. A third party like Supreme Court should hear and give verdict. And once the Supreme Court gives verdict, everybody will accept it. If Ram himself speaks in favour of Sita, then people will say, Oh, look how Ram has become so blindly attached to his wife. He obviously speaks in favour of his wife. He is so lusty. He is attached to his wife. So Ram did not take the side of mother Sita. So he distanced himself from the queen.

segments.key_quote: Valmiki gave his verdict that Sita is, she has spotless character.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Valmiki, a respected sage, vouched for Sita's character, similar to a Supreme Court verdict, leading to her reacceptance as queen.
segments.transcript: But as husband, he always gave the position of a great wife to mother Sita. Later, in another authority in the society, in Treta Yuga, the great sages were given the great authority. Like the kings, they were also authorities. When Valmiki comes and he says with his tapas shakti of 60,000 years of tapasya, he says, I vouch for the character of Sita. And everybody now accepts. He accepts the statement of Valmiki because Valmiki does not have any favouritism, right? Because Sita is no way connected to Valmiki. And Valmiki, who was so pure with his tapas shakti, who has that faith and trust in the public, the public was ready to accept the statement of Valmiki. And when he said that Sita is clean, Sita's character is pure, then Ram said she can come back as the queen of Ayodhya. So, like Supreme Court gave verdict, Valmiki gave his verdict that Sita is, she has spotless character.

segments.key_quote: Ram has dual roles to play. He has a role of a king, role of a husband.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing Sita's acceptance of Ram's actions, understanding his dual roles as king and husband, and highlighting Ram's sacrifice and nationalistic leadership.
segments.transcript: At that time, Ram was ready to welcome mother Sita. If at all Ram mistreated his wife Sita, he doubted the character of Sita, he has hurt the feelings and emotions of Sita, then what was Sita's response to this? The Sita's response itself will tell us, that how she was happy with Sri Ram's action of sending her to forest. At the end, mother Sita asked that life after life, I want Sri Ram as my husband. If Sri Ram mistreated her, why she wants Sri Ram again as her husband? That itself will tell us, clarify all the doubts, as a responsible, mature queen, Sita understood the Dharma Sankat of Ram. Ram has dual roles to play. He has a role of a king, role of a husband. So, the family of Lord Sri Ram always stood by country, stood by the welfare of the citizen, not the personal happiness, personal benefit. When it was about to do Pattabhisheka, become king, at that time also Ram chose Ayodhya first, his personal happiness later. He went to forest in order to demonstrate the entire citizen, here is a government that always keeps up the promise. It never goes away from the words, the promises that we have made, Raghukula Reethi Sada Chaliyai. Even at the cost of being in the forest and going through so much tribulation, even at this case, Lord Sri Ram is being away from such loving wife, just to show to the people, the whole world that how a leader always chooses his duty first, country first, welfare of the citizen first, and family is last. He is never a Parivarwadi, in fact he is a Rashtravadi. He is a great, true, inspiring, nationalistic leader
